text: An impressive room serving as an ARTIST’S WORKSHOP. It’s empty, but evidence of frantic creative activity abounds. We PAN across the wall, crossing a series of meticulously hand-crafted DOLLHOUSES, mostly works in progress. As we drift past these unfinished dioramas, our trajectory beco clearer... We are moving in on an extraordinary sculpture of a beautiful, rustic CRAFTSMAN HOME, at 1:8 scale. Its front wall has been removed, exposing its rooms in graphic tableaux. This huge miniature is painstakingly detailed. adorned with shrunken props/decorations (flashlights, pil bottles, shoes, etc.) and teensy furniture, all flawlessl rendered and distinguishable ONLY IN SIZE from their full scale models. We continue to pan/track across the miniature, edging CLO AND CLOSER as we drift along its tiny rooms. We finally arrive at a miniature replica of a TEENAGE BOY’S BEDROOM the second floor. We push towards this until the ROOM FILLS THE FRAME. The bright morning sun beams in through its window. It become apparent that a handsome, skinny BOY is sleeping in the b This is PETER GRAHAM (17). We continue pushing gently in, remaining in a wide of the room (whose status as a miniature has now been confused). door opens and STEVE GRAHAM (47) - tall, broad-shouldered formal - pops his head in. He wears a black suit.
All right, Petey. Wake up time. Peter stirs awake. Steve drops a folded-up BLACK SUIT AND on the foot of the bed.
Here’s your suit. MAX, the family’s golden retriever, shuffles happily in through the door.
Did your sister sleep in her room last night?

Wide on the house, revealing that it is IDENTICAL to the miniature that we saw in the workshop. The surrounding landscape is blanketed with SNOW.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 2. Steve exits a back door to approach a very large TREEHOUS It is joined to a sturdy oak and hovers fifteen feet abov the ground. We are subtly BOOMING DOWN from this wide vie (as Steve begins to climb the tree) to arrive at a parked - one of two family cars - in the foreground. Sitting in the passenger seat is a bereaved woman (45). S wears all black, and is beautiful in a worn way. This is ANNIE GRAHAM, and she looks emotionally exhausted. She wears a delicate NECKLACE bearing an ORNATE SIGIL, wh she compulsively fingers.

Steve pokes his head into the treehouse, where he finds: CHARLIE - a plump, androgynous fourteen year old girl - l asleep on the floor. She wears a parka and pajama bottoms Beside her is a DRAWING PAD and an open SHOEBOX.
Oh my God, Charlie. Are you crazy? Charlie wakes up, her nose pink and runny. When she notic Steve, she frantically reaches to SHUT the shoebox.
This is how you get pneumonia!
(getting up) It’s okay.
Your mom’s in the car already, we're late.

A moderately attended FUNERAL. (A large group of MEN AND WOMEN observe from the back.) Before the altar, an OPEN CASKET rests beside a blown up photo of the deceased ELLEN LEIGH, Annie’s 75 year old mother. Annie, Steve, Charlie (now wearing an oversized black dre over her pajama bottoms) and Peter sit in the first row o chairs. They listen as a LARGE WOMAN (60s) speaks in remembrance of Ellen.
Ellen was a tough one. She didn't mince words, she abhorred the sentimental, and she was honest. And I know that's how she raised her children, Annie and Charles - (MORE )
Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 3.

(uncomfortably) - may he rest in peace... To always be honest... Half-listening (half-wincing), Annie’s attention is drawn CHARLIE, who makes a quiet CLICKING noise with her tongue This is a tic. Suddenly, a bird FLAPS out from the rafters, startling th congregation. The bird settles on a ceiling perch. It is a WHIPPOORWILL looks down, fixing its gaze on Annie. Annie looks very disturbed. Off-screen, the Large Woman continues.
Annie is now on the PLATFORM.

I just wanna say first...it’s very heartening to see so many strange new faces here today. I know my mom would be very touched (and probably a little suspicious) if she could see this turn-out, so... Annie looks down to now read from a heavily edited loose- page. This is her eulogy. (Not used to reading in public, rarely looks up from the paper.)

My mother was an intensely secretive and private woman. She had private rituals, private friends, private anxieties... It honestly feels like a betrayal just to be standing here talking about her... Annie pauses. She looks at the paragraph. It’s very long, begins with the sentence “My mother was a chameleon." She decides to skip ahead to the next paragraph.

She was a very difficult woman to read. If you ever thought you knew what was going on with her - and God forbid you tried to confront that.../ (stops...pauses...skips ahead) ...But when her life was unpolluted, she could easily be the sweetest, warmest, most loving person in the world...  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 4. Charlie is DRAWING a weepy caricature of Annie at the platform. Steve watches this in the corner of his eye.
(pauses, skips again to the next paragraph) .-.-She was also incredibly stubborn. Which maybe explains me. Scattered, knowing laughter.

You could always count on her to always have the answer.... She stops short, eyes on the paper. The sentence would continue “and if she ever WAS mistaken - well, that was Y opinion and you were WRONG.” Suddenly remorseful, Annie (off-book) asserts:
I did love her. Charlie is still drawing. Steve closes the notepad. He po to Annie: “Listen to your mother." Charlie grudgingly obliges.
She was especially strong about food. When I was a girl and I had to eat my veggies...

The mourners have been invited up to view the deceased an say goodbye. Organ music plays as Annie, Steve, Peter (wh doesn’t look) and Charlie shuffle by. Charlie peers into the open casket to see her grandmother CORPSE. It wears a NECKLACE with a delicate SIGIL ORNAMEN (identical to Annie’s). The seams in the corpse’s make-up eerily apparent and the lips are slightly twisted. Unnerved, Charlie looks away. She meets eyes with a smili MIDDLE-AGED BLONDE MAN standing in the queue behind her. STARING at her - an overly sentimental look in his eyes. Disturbed, Charlie averts her eyes. “Yeesh."”

An older WOMAN arrives at the open casket. Her finger is dipped into a small bottle of OIL. She quickly and covert STREAKS the oil along the corpse’s lips. Seeing this, a following mourner squints with bewildermen  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 5.
Steve is at the wheel, driving back home. Annie sits passenger, and Peter and Charlie sit in the back. They dr past a gathering of DEER.
(to Steve) How did you keep from screaming during Judy’s speech?

Ha. Well, if you could...! Peter EYES the back of Annie’s head. She seems to grate o his nerves. Meanwhile, Charlie is back to making clicking noises with her tongue. She does this while unwrapping a CHOCOLATE BAR.
(to Steve) How about that bird flying in?
Yeah, that was weird.
That was too weird. The timing? It felt like it was my mom. Steve nods, betraying a look of CONCERN. Annie self- consciously backtracks:
Not actually, obviously. Just - it struck me. Annie notices Charlie eating the chocolate bar.
Hey! Are there nuts in that?
No!
Better not be. Annie returns her attention to the road. Steve lovingly t her hand. She smiles at him. Charlie, irritated, looks very tense.
(quietly) I don’t like going back without grandma.
(carefully) Well, sweetie...do you understand why we have to?
Charlie just tenses up, eyes narrowing onto the floor.

The house is unlit and seemingly vacant. Off-screen, we hear FEET SCURRYING and a DOOR CLOSING. Ma the golden retriever, BARKS in reaction to this. A moment later, the front door opens and the Graham famil enters. They stamp the snow off their boots and remove th coats. Max runs up, desperate to greet them. Steve bends down to happily receive him. Charlie moves toward the stairs, still wearing her boots.
Hey hey -- shoes off. Charlie pulls off her boots. She and Peter start separate up the stairs. Steve, looking down, notices dried FOOT-PR around the foyer.
(calling out) See? What’s with all these footprints? I’m tired of reminding everybody.

Annie is at her work desk. It’s a mess of paints, props, pieces, etc. She wears magnifying eye-glasses as she carefully paints eyes onto a SMALL DOCTOR FIGURINE for a MINIATURE HOSPICE. A figurine of an old woman - presumabl Annie’s mother - lies in a miniature hospital bed. Steve enters, disrupting Annie’s focus.
How's it going?
Just working. Steve casually rests a glass of water and a PILL on the table. She downs it without question.
Still toiling on the hospice?  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 7.
Between that and the pre-school. There is a half-finished MINIATURE PRE-SCHOOL in the corn
How far are we now? Seven months?
Six and a half.
Yow. Comin’ up. Her eyes widen with stress.

Any title ideas yet? Annie grabs her laptop and pulls up a PDF for a poster promoting an upcoming EXHIBITION of her artwork. It featu a photo of a magnificent living room miniature. Below thi are the words “TITLE HERE” in bold, followed by “The Work Annie Leigh.”
This is the photo they wanna use. Ooh, I love that one.
The gallery owner keeps suggesting Your Life in Miniature for the title.
What do you think of that? Annie looks at him, incredulous. “Are you serious?”
No good?
It’s horrible!
(conceding) Yeah. A little trite.
A lot trite! Are you kidding? She won't stop suggesting it! Steve looks to a stack of LARGE MOVING BOXES in the corne They're marked “Mom’s Things” in Annie’s handwriting.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 8.
You want me to put that stuff in the attic?

...-Yeah. Maybe not just yet. INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 8 Peter sits up in bed, holding a guitar. He improvises a clunky tune as a muted TV plays cartoons. His eyes are on TV. The door cracks open and Steve pokes his head in.
Goodnight, kiddo.
‘Night, dad.
..-What you playing?
Just plucking random strings.
(nods, then) You feeling okay about everything?
(shrugs ) Yeah. Fine.
Little sad? Peter shrugs again. He clearly wasn’t fond of Ellen.

Yeah. I know. (pause) Okay, buddy. Love you. Steve KISSES in Peter’s direction. Peter kisses back. Ste walks off, leaving the door open. A moment later, Annie walks up to the doorway, still wear her magnifying eye-glasses. She’s holding a prop in one h a fine paintbrush in the other.
‘Night sweetheart.
Goodnight. I’m sorry about your mom.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 9.
(pause) Thank you. I’m sorry about your grandma.

..-Thank you. Annie smiles, hesitates, and walks off. There’s a very lo tension between these two. After Annie is gone, Peter climbs out of bed to shut the door. He LOCKS it. INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 9 Charlie’s room is that of a young artist. The walls are covered in drawings, and the desks and other surfaces are littered with different HANDMADE HUMAN MANIKINS and SMALL STATUES (all made of disparate parts - mostly found objec Annie sits on the edge of Charlie’s bed. Charlie is under covers. Annie has opened Charlie’s drawing pad to see a CARICATURE of Annie’s mother’s corpse in its casket.
That’s grandma?
I dunno.
You know you were her favorite?
(looking away) No I wasn’t.
(pouncing) Oh yes you absolutely were! Even when you were a little baby, she wouldn't let me feed you because she needed to feed you. It drove me crazy.
She said I was supposed to be a boy. Annie knows this. She hesitates, wanting to say the right thing.
How do you feel about that? Charlie shrugs.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 10.
You know I was a tomboy growing up? I hated dresses and dolls and pink. Charlie’s heard this before. She has tensed up.
(looking away, quietly) Who’s gonna take care of me?
(mock offended) Ummm, excuse me? You don’t think I’m gonna take care of you?!
But when you die...
..+.-Then dad will take care of you. Or Peter. Charlie’s head remains turned. Discouraged, Annie turns b the page of the drawing pad. She now sees the caricature her, crying at the pulpit.
Who's this one? No answer. Annie takes it personally, but pretends not to She closes the book with a smile.
You never even cried as a baby - you know that? Not even when you were born. Charlie ignores this.
Did you feel like you wanted to cry today? Without looking at Annie, Charlie shrugs a tense “I don’t know.”

Do you think that might feel like a relief? Charlie remains miles away. Annie looks up to notice that a difficult-to-read WORD (l like “Satony”) has been CARVED into the wall behind Charl bed. Annie pauses, lets it go, and then bends down to KIS Charlie’s forehead.  10 11 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 11.
Goodnight, sweetie.

Annie enters. Outside the window: peaceful snowfall. Annie hesitates before walking over to the box labeled “M Things." She reluctantly opens it... The box is filled with bottled oils and herbs. At the top the box is a PHOTO ALBUM titled “Memories.” Annie opens i sift through photos of her mother. She lays the album bac into the box, and then notices a stack of worn HARDBACKS. pulls one out. “NOTES ON SPIRITUALISM.” This calls back unwelcome memories. Annie dumps the book into the box, and PUSHES the box away. Annie walks to the door and flips off the light, leaving room in darkness (save for the moonlight). She’s about to leave, but something makes her FREEZE. Standing motionless in a dark corner (almost too dark to out) is ANNIE’S MOTHER, ELLEN - wearing the same outfit a the funeral. She’s staring at Annie. SMILING. Annie, nearly paralyzed with fear, reaches for the light switch. Without looking away, she turns the light back ON Her mother is gone. Annie remains motionless.

(a whisper) Mom? Annie's eyes are now drawn to... A dusty older MINIATURE in the corner. It's a replica of Annie's bedroom. A figurine of Annie (in her early thirti BREASTFEEDS a baby. Standing beside her is a figurine of OLDER WOMAN (Annie’s mother) holding her naked BREAST out her nightgown. She leans over, offering it to the baby. Competing with Annie. Troubled by this, Annie walks briskly to the miniature an TURNS it away. It’s now facing the wall as Annie returns the door, flicks off the light, and leaves. INT. ANNIE & STEVE’S BEDROOM - MINUTES LATER 11 Annie climbs into bed with Steve.
I just scared myself in the workshop.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 12.
Oh no. With what? Annie pauses. Thinks about telling him. Steve looks interested/slightly worried. Annie thinks better of it.
. No? She smiles “nah.”
Goodnight. Annie turns off the bedside lamp and gives Steve a blunt kiss.
(before she can pull away ) Mm, mm - no you don’t. He EXTENDS the kiss, making it last. Then:
Goodnight.

Charlie’s “special needs” class. Scrawled on the blackboard are the words “Quiet means Silence!” and all the students are indeed silent as they a quiz. (warmly) So maybe we finish the toy after the quiz? What do you think?

...Okay. The teacher gently turns the quiz right-side-up. Charlie extremely tense through this.  13 13. Suddenly a PIGEON flies into the window, slamming its hea The impact breaks its neck. The classroom erupts with excitement - “Oh my God!” “Did see that?!” - but not Charlie. She stares tensely at her desk, still disturbed by the teacher's interference. Charlie’s EYES scan up. They alight on a pair of SCISSORS the Teacher’s desk.

Peter’s English class. The chalkboard reads: Themes - Escaping Fate. - Relationship between knowledge and responsibility. - "No man considered fortunate until he is dead." The teacher, MR. DAVIES (30s), tries to facilitate a grou discussion. He holds a copy of Sophocles’ The Women of Trachis.
So if we're going by the rule that a hero is undone by his fatal flaw, what was Heracles’ flaw?
Fucking his mom. Some laughter from the class.
Wrong play, Sam. And watch your language. Meanwhile, Peter is being hypnotized by BRIDGET (17), the attractive girl sitting in front of him. Peter’s rapt attention is glued to the butt of her jeans.
Come on, guys: What was Heracles’ flaw? Bridget now speaks up:
Arrogance. This piques Peter’s interest.
Okay - why?  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 14.
Because he literally refuses to look at all the signs that are being literally handed to him the entire play. Peter’s in love.
Okay, interesting! So he thinks he has control.
Plus he fucked his mom. More laughs.

(to the smart-ass) That’s two strikes, Sam. (back to the class) But also, don’t forget: Sophocles writes it so the oracle is unconditional. Meaning Heracles never had any choice. Right? Peter’s smartphone VIBRATES with a text.
So, does this make it more tragic or less tragic than if he did have a choice?
Less! Peter checks his text. It’s from Brendan. It reads: “Wann smoke a bowl at break?” This came from the BOY behind him
Okay: Why?
(already giving up) Because! Mr. Davies turns to Peter, who’s now composing a text in lap.
Care to weigh in, Peter? Peter looks up, a deer in headlights.
About which part?  14 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 15.
Is it more tragic if it’s inevitable than if the characters had agency? Peter is not following.
Yes?
Why?
.-.-Because he had sex with his mom? Dead air. Mr. Davies gives Peter an unencouraging look. Another student picks up the slack:

I think it's more tragic - because if it’s all just inevitable, that means the characters have no hope and that they never had hope, because they’re just like pawns in this horrible, hopeless machine. Peter has now noticed BRIDGET looking at him. She gives h sardonic “nice try” smile. Peter smiles back, embarrassed She turns away. Peter’s smile turns to a longing stare.

Recess. The DEAD PIGEON lies pathetically in the bushes below Charlie’s classroom window. Charlie stands nearby, staring at the pigeon. After some time, she fishes a pair of SCISSORS from her parka pocket (These are the scissors from her teacher's desk.) Charlie extends the scissors, fits the blades around the pigeon’s neck, and SNIPS OFF ITS HEAD. Charlie quickly POCKETS the pigeon head, and looks up to notice: An OLDER WOMAN (60s) sitting on a bench, just beyond the schoolyard fence. She is gazing at Charlie, sentimental. Charlie gawks at the woman, unnerved. Without breaking ey contact, she pulls a chocolate bar from her pocket. In the b.g., PETER walks past, joined by Brendan. Seeing chocolate, Peter casually asserts:  15 16 17 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 16.

No nuts, Charlie. This makes Charlie freeze up with tension. INT. PSYCHIATRIST’S OFFICE - AFTERNOON 15 Steve’s office is large and sparsely decorated. Steve sits in a leather chair with a notepad resting on h lap. Sitting opposite him is an extremely agitated, depre female PATIENT (40s). Steve studies her non-judgmentally.
And how’s the anger?
Same. I just don’t care as much.
(optimistic) So not as consuming?
(gritted teeth) It's just as consuming, I just don’t care as much. Steve, stifling frustration, affects superhuman patience.

Were you in my mom’s room?

Okay.

I don’t think you need to worry about me ever being in that room.
Steve is at Annie’s Mother’s door. He LOCKS IT (by key) f the outside.
Sorry. I know it’s irrational.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 18.
Not at all. Illustrating that it’s locked, Steve tries turning the kn Annie smiles.
Thank you. She kisses Steve, feeling dopey. Peter walks up to them, holding the PHONE.
Dad? (extending phone) It’s the cemetery.
About what?
I‘ll see. (into phone) Hi... Yeah... Steve walks down the hall to create distance between him Annie. Now irked, Annie walks off.
(into phone, warily) Okay.... And what does “desecrated” mean? (listens, then - shocked) What? It's only been a week. ANNIE steps back into the hall, now wearing a coat. Steve nervously accelerates:
(into phone) Okay. All right. Can I actually call you back?... Okay, fine. Steve hangs up.

I’m gonna go see a movie.  20 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 19.

..-Want me to join?

Okay...great. I think you should. Annie smiles “thanks.”
Do you know where Charlie is?
Where else? Annie knows what that means. She immediately looks frustrated.
Let it go. It’s wasted energy.

Charlie sits in her treehouse. She lays the severed pigeo head into her SHOEBOX. Inside this box are three other SEVERED ANIMAL HEADS. One belongs to a rabbit, one to a r one to a squirrel. (The heads are in different stages of decomposition; flies buzz about.) Down below, Annie is heard:
Charlie? Charlie shuts the box, SHOVES it into a corner, and peers down to see ANNIE at the tree’s base.
Come on, sweetie. It’s freezing out here. No response from Charlie. Annie doesn’t push it. ced  21 22 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 20.

(defensively) Why??
Annie idles into the parking lot of a Catholic high schoo She parks, turns off the engine, and sits in silence for moment. Bracing herself.

A SUPPORT GROUP held in the high school’s gymnasium. A si on an easel reads “LOSING A LOVED ONE, Grief Recovery." T session hasn’t yet started. Twenty empty chairs form a CI in the space’s center. Mourners of varying affect are scattered about, mingling. Annie ENTERS, very ill-at-ease.
All the chairs are now filled. A middle-aged MEXICAN WOMA speaks (in Spanish) through coursing tears. A YOUNG MAN translates for her as the rest of the group listens.

(translating between her sentences) Sometimes I even get so relieved... Because he was in so much pain, and by the end he just hated himself. Always saying “I’m a burden, I’ma burden, I’m a burden”... Annie’s eyes are wide. She’s empathizing with this, but i seems to also be agitating her.
The GROUP LEADER addresses the group.
We've set aside some time for any newcomers who might like to speak... Silence.  21.
So, anybody new - if it’s your first or second time with us: the floor is open. Annie looks very torn. She starts to lift up her hand, bu stops short.
(gesturing to Annie) Yes? Annie looks panicked.
Would you like to...?

Okay. No pressure. Annie nods, takes a long moment, and then forces herself:
My name’s Annie.
Hi Annie. Annie strains a smile. She continues tensely, as if again her will:

My mom died a week ago, so I’m just here for - trying it. I have a lot of resistance to things like this, but I went to these a couple years ago - I was pressured to come - but it did help, so... (long pause) My mom was old and she wasn’t all together at the end - and we were pretty much estranged before that - so it wasn’t a huge blow. But I did love her. And she didn’t have an easy life... She had D.I.D., which became extreme in the last year, and dementia...! My dad died of starvation when I was a baby. He had psychotic depression and he starved himself. Which I’m sure was as pleasant as it sounds. And then my older brother - he was schizophrenic - and when he was sixteen, he hanged himself in my mom’s bedroom. (MORE )

Of course his suicide note blamed her. Accusing her of putting people inside of him. (throws hands up) So that was my mom’s life! Annie looks to the group. They allow her time to continue She reluctantly proceeds.

.--She finally lived in our house at the end. Before hospice. And I don’t wanna put any more stress on my family. Not even sure if they could give me that support. She gets stuck here. Tears begin to well. She struggles t squeeze out the following:
It just all sometimes feels ruined. And then I realize I'm to blame. Or not that I'm to blame, but that I'm...blamed. Beat.

I apparently acted a certain way - according to them - I did things, in my sleep, a couple years ago. Or almost did them...  23 24 25 26 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 23. So anyway. Everything's disappointing. So here I am. She forces a laugh, but also cries a bit. She wipes away tears and makes an embarrassed “bah” face. She then motio to the group: “Who’s next?”

Is Charlie here?

INT. ANNIE & STEVE’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 108 ANNIE WAKES UP WITH A START. It was all a dream. Max is barking wildly in the hallway. A FLY lands on Annie’s face. Peter sits tensely in the back corner of his classroom. The teacher stands at the blackboard, leading the class through an algebra lesson. Peter’s mind is a storm. He’s brought fiercely into the present, however, when a strange, barely perceptible glin LIGHT (we've seen this before) FLASHES across the room. T light ends at the WINDOW next to Peter. Peter looks around. Nobody else noticed it. Peter blinks few times, concerned that he might be seeing things. He t back to the window to see... Peter’s REFLECTION is staring pointedly back at him. The color drains from Peter’s face. He looks weakly back his own reflection, whose eyes HARDEN bitterly against hi Overwhelmed, Peter abruptly STANDS UP, distracting the teacher.
Yes, Peter?
(confused) I - have to go to the bathroom.  112 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 85. Aware of Peter’s recent trauma, the Teacher is careful to extra-sensitive.

That’s fine. Just take the pass. Peter leaves, tears in his eyes. INT. STEVE’S OFFICE - DAY 111 Steve sits stiffly at the computer in his office. He has typed into his search engine “Paranormal evidence, voice channeling,” but he pauses and then DELETES this. He inst writes “Symptomatology and management of grief hallucinations.” He presses SEND. Steve looks over the results, and then clicks on a separa tab. It’s a half-composed EMAIL to a fellow psychiatrist. email reads... Hi Bob, I hesitate to write, but I’m worried that Annie might be the verge of (or in the MIDDLE of) He’s stuck on how to continue. Steve’s cell phone rings. It’s an unknown number. He hesitates before answering it.
Hello? There’s a strange wave of STATIC and then...
(almost whispering) Dad?
Peter? We can hear that Peter is crying, near hysteria.
Something’s at the school.

What is? It followed me here! INT. ANNIE’S WORKSHOP - SAME TIME 112 The cordless PHONE is ringing. Two FLIES crawl across it. Annie, still wearing her nightgown, nervously works on a FUNERAL HOME model. The ringing STOPS, but then starts ag Annie now turns to ANSWER the phone.  86.
Hello? Steve is on the other end. We can hear that he is DRIVING
(furious) Can you guess who just called me from school in complete hysterics? Annie goes pale.
(gravely) Charlie?
...What?
I -- nothing. What happened?
Peter just called me, Annie. Terrified. Crying in the halls. He’s convinced he’s being threatened by some vengeful spirit.
Why does he think he’s being threatened?
(no patience) Listen to me, Annie: I have a son to protect.
What does that mean?
It means that’s what I’m worried about right now. That’s how I’m proceeding.
Don’t talk to me like this. He’s my son, too. CLICK. He’s hung up. Infuriated, Annie calls Steve back. He answers.

Don’t hang up on me again. I’m not sleepwalking anymore, you understand? She hangs up.  113 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 87. Annie returns to the miniature funeral home. She carefull (but tensely) presses a freshly GLUED piece of balsa wood against the beautifully rendered wall. She holds it in pl The phone RINGS. Annie doesn’t care. It rings until the ANSWERING MACHINE gets it. After the outgoing message, th machine BEEPS and a WOMAN leaves a message.

Hi Annie! It’s Margaret at the Asher Gallery. I’m just calling to see how things are with you and your family - I hope everything’s okay — and also, just wondering, uh, how the progress is going. Not that you need reminding - haha - but we are a little less than nine weeks away, so it would just be nice to get the vaguest sense of where we are. So yeah, call me back whenever, and again, I really hope everything’s okay and our thoughts are all very much with your family, so - Okay. Thanks so much. Click. BEEP. Annie has grown extremely TENSE over the course of that message. Still applying pressure to the glued-on piece, s pushes a little too hard, and her thumb BREAKS THROUGH th miniature’s wall. Annie FREEZES for a moment, shocked. Then, overcome by sh frustration, she raises her FIST and SMASHES IT DOWN into funeral home’s floor, SNAPPING it. Taken by a surge of destructive rage, she SWEEPS the miniature off the table and rises to STOMP her foot throu its roof. DESTROYING IT. Without missing a beat, she grabs a HAMMER and proceeds t SMASH APART the rest of her miniatures. It’s a woeful, devastating fit. By the time Annie gets a grip on herself it’s too late. All of the pieces have been destroyed. All except for one... The MINIATURE OF THE GRAHAM HOUSE. Annie drops the hammer.
Steve and Peter enter through the front door. A bad SMELL immediately hits them.
Whoa. Jesus. They proceed up the stairs. Steve swipes away a fly.  114 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 88.
Did something die in here?
Peter goes to his room, closing the door behind him. Steve walks up to the WORKSHOP’s door. He opens it withou knocking.
(entering) Annie, what is that smell-- But he FREEZES when he sees the state of the demolished r Annie sits in her chair, completely surrounded by smashed splintered wood.
(stunned) ...What happened? He looks at Annie and almost immediately understands. She this. His heart breaks.
I didn’t wanna look at it anymore. Steve stares at her for a very long time. He then grabs t PHONE and storms into the hallway, dialing a number.
(rising) Hey! Who are you calling?!

Through the upstairs hallway window, A CAR pulls up to pa behind Steve’s car. A pleasant, well scrubbed man (50s) emerges to walk toward the house. This is DR. STETSON. There is a KNOCK at the door. It is heard OPENING.
Hi Steve.
Thanks for coming, Bob. Yeah: forgive the smell. I think something died in the walls. Annie is standing in the upstairs hallway, listening.

(sighs) She’s upstairs right now.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 89. Annie takes this as her cue. She walks defiantly down the stairs. She arrives at the bottom, in the FOYER. Dr. Stet acknowledges her with a big smile.
(warmly ) Hi Annie.
Dr. Stetson.
Can we all sit somewhere and talk?

(disdainful) Yeah, let’s make ourselves at home. Annie sits in a chair in the corner. Dr. Stetson takes a chair and brings it nearer. Stetson sits across from Anni without crowding her. (A couple flies will be buzzing aro throughout.)
How's it going?
Not amazing.
Can you talk about why?
(blunt) Uh - because my daughter was killed and now my psychiatrist husband is calling over his peers to investigate me. Steve glowers.
Nobody's investigating you, Annie. Annie just stares at him. DR. STETSON (CONT’D) Can I ask how you are?
I'm fine. I’m lucid. I’m in mourning and I’m trying to cope, and he’s supposed to be my partner, so forgive me if I’m not bouncing off the walls to see you.  90.
Nobody's trying to do anything against you right now, Annie. I promise you.
Then stop patronizing me please. Stetson takes a long pause. He levels with her:
What’s all this about ghosts? And seances?
(direct) I thought I felt a presence. I was hopeful, as you can imagine. It was fleeting, and now I’m back to grieving.
Okay... All right. (moving on) And why did you destroy your work?
(turning back to Stetson) Because it’s my work. Annie's eyes are stone. Brief pause.

(relenting) Fair enough. So I’m gonna ask you some annoying questions now, Annie. (making sure to not patronize) I can see that you're lucid. This is just simply what I have to do. Okay? (first question) What day is it?
Tuesday.

When in the month? 115 Through the foyer window, we see Steve and Dr. Stetson OUTSIDE. This is from Annie’s POV. Dr. Stetson seems to be explaining something to Steve. St nods, frustrated.  116 91. We see Dr. Stetson say “I’m sorry, I can’t” and then he w off to his car. Steve sulks back toward the house. Steve enters. He looks at Annie.

What were you hoping? That I'd tell your psychiatrist friend that we brought back our dead daughter? You think I don’t know how that sounds? Steve nods, numb. He walks past her, toward the stairs. A pauses before following him up. INT. ANNIE’S WORKSHOP - MOMENTS LATER 116 Steve has entered the workshop. He walks heavily around t ruins. Annie steps in. Watches him.
You worked so hard for this show.
Jesus Christ - Fuck the show. You're ignoring this!
I’m not ignoring anything - believe me. Long pause.
(tensely, measuredly) I won’t indulge this behavior anymore.
I won’t. I can’t allow it.
You ignore everything! If you can’t find it in one of your books!
“Indulge”?

“Allow” now! Jesus! Listen to how you’re just clinging! (pointing) You’re the one who’s gonna go crazy, Steve. If you keep just denying what’s in front of you. Steve stares at her, overwhelmed. He looks down to notice his feet: the figurine of Annie’s Mother, holding out her breast. Steve lets out a defeated sigh.
(tears building) You know, Annie... (MORE )
Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 92.
You can still build a shrine to the terrible stuff. Doesn’t mean you have to destroy anything good.
Well, it’s not anything good. It’s nothing. It means nothing. This -— (kicks a piece of wood) - is what I cared about.
Except for that one. Steve is pointing out the pristine Graham House replica. looks it over. Something makes him chuckle bitterly to himself.

Rattled and extremely tense, Steve sits at the couch, whi is dressed with a blanket and pillow. He uncaps a PRESCRIPTION BOTTLE (sleeping pills).  118 119 120 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 93.

Suddenly she HEARS the faint sound of a PENCIL VIGOROUSLY SCRATCHING PAPER. It’s coming from down the hall. She hesitates before rising and entering the HALLWAY... More and more flies have collected. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS 119 The door is open. The lights are OFF. The sound of PENCIL FEVERISHLY SCRATCHING PAPER is heard, although the room i completely empty. Annie stands at the door. PETER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 120 The door is closed and the lights are off. Peter is inbed trying to sleep. Silence, save for a buzzing fly. Then... A CLICKING of the tongue. Peter’s eyes OPEN. He slowly lo up, scanning past the bed, to SEE... CHARLIE is standing in the dark corner of the room (where Peter mistook his hoodie for a person). Charlie stares at Peter with unblinking eyes. Charlie? A long silence. Charlie slowly opens her MOUTH, but then head DROOPS forward and rolls OFF her shoulders. The door SLAMS SHUT.

Peter! Peter! INT. PETER’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 123 Peter has just been released by the phantom hands. He’s frantic. ANNIE is now standing in the room.
What’s wrong, baby?! What happened?!
What are you doing?!  124 95.
What do you mean?!
You were pulling on my head!
What?! Peter looks terrified of her.
No I wasn’t! I just came in! You were screaming! Peter is crying.
What happened?
I saw Charlie in the corner and then you started pulling on my head.
Peter! I would never do that to you! Are you crazy? I would never hurt you. How could you even think that? Peter just stares at her through frightened tears.

Listen to me, Peter. I don’t know what’s happening or what you just saw, but I’m stopping this. Do NOT tell dad what you just said to me. Please. It's NOT true. Something’s going on, and I’m the only one who can stop this. Do you understand? I’m the only one who can fix it. Peter stares unblinkingly at her. INT. CHARLIE’S BEDROOM - SAME TIME 124 Charlie’s DRAWING PAD is open. We track slowly in, reveal the CONTENT of two of the drawings... Both are crude, violently drawn sketches of PETER’S FACE, the EYES are replaced with X’s. The faces are framed by furiously sketched TRIANGLES.  125 126 127 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 96. A BREEZE blows in from the window, flipping to the NEXT P more of the same - and then the next page - still more of same - and then the next page, etc... Annie’s HAND enters to seize the drawing pad. She leaves room. Max's barking persists in the b.g.

Annie has started a FIRE in the fireplace. (In theb.g., Steve is still asleep on the couch.) Annie watches this, eyes glued to the fire. But the shoul of her SHIRT has sprouted the tiny beginning of a FLAME. is the same size as the burgeoning flame at the drawing p edge. The MOON hangs large over the house. We then SLAM CUT to MORNING. The moon has been replaced by a shrill SUN.

Behind the workshop door: ANNIE stares through the crack, making sure that Peter leaves.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 97. 128 INT. JOAN’S APARTMENT BUILDING - THIRD FLOOR - MOMENT Annie, looking frighteningly determined, emerges from the elevator of JOAN’S BUILDING. She’s still wearing her nightgown under a coat. She rushes to JOAN’S DOOR and kno No answer. Annie knocks again, more urgently. 129 INT. JOAN’S APARTMENT - CONTINUOUS 129 Nobody's home. We are pulling back from the DOOR (as Anni knocking persists) to REVEAL the apartment... It looks mostly the same, but it’s now adorned in cloths drapes that feature various SYMBOLS. One of these is an ORNATE SIGIL (which we recognize as the one on Annie’s necklace). This is the Sigil of PAIMON, and it can now be found all over the room. The TABLE at which Annie and Joan performed the seance (w was then covered in a table-cloth) is now bare, revealing that the tabletop has a LARGE TRIANGLE carved into it (pointing to the northwest). Resting in the middle of the triangle is a PHOTO OF PETER. Beside this is an ATHAME (ritual dagger), a scattering of herbs, and finally... A primitive DIORAMA (the same that we saw earlier on Charlie’s desk, but now finished). Standing center stage crude manikin of a human torso whose head is an actual SEVERED RAVEN HEAD. Atop the head is an aluminum-foil CRO Three other sculptures BOW ON THEIR KNEES to the raven-he figure. Their heads are the severed PIGEON HEAD (now decomposing), a severed RAT HEAD and a severed SQUIRREL H Annie's knocking continues.

Annie ceases knocking. She looks DOWN to notice that she’ standing on... The WELCOME MAT. “JOANIE.” Annie's mind starts racing. She thinks for a moment and t it hits her! Annie RACES back to the elevator. A SCHOOL BELL RINGS, bridging our CUT TO:

LUNCH TIME. It’s overcast, dark and windy. Students mill about in flapping clothes. Just beyond the high school fence is a ROAD with heavy traffic. PETER is seated at an empty table near the fence eating (or rather, not eating) the cafeteria food.  132 Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 98. The TRAFFIC NOISE is loud and imposing. Peter LISTENS to losing himself in the white noise. But there’s something looming underneath the traffic noise... It's like a distant YELLING, but too distant to make out. Slowly it becomes clearer, more distinct. It’s a WOMAN’S VOICE and it’s yelling “Peter.” Peter looks up. Where is it coming from?

(still vague) ...I expel you...! Peter looks around. Soon his eyes settle on something... Across the road, on a far sidewalk, JOAN is standing. She looks raving mad. She’s staring directly at Peter and she screaming like a lunatic.
Terrified, Peter rises from his seat. He looks around to if anyone else is noticing this. Nobody is.
Peter looks back at her. They MEET EYES.
Peter breaks the gaze. He looks around, appealing to any/ of the circulating kids. It’s clear that none of them see hear this. How is that possible?

INT. ANNIE’S WORKSHOP - DAY 132 Annie runs in from the hallway. She rushes to the BOXES marked “Mom’s Things.” She opens first box and finds a HAND-EMBROIDERED WELCOME MAT. It’s exact same style as Joan’s. Embroidered into it is the na “ANNIE”. Under that is another mat, bearing the name “CHARLES” and featuring the now-familiar sigil of PAIMON. Annie goes to the next box. She dig through a collection herbs and oils, and beneath those, she finds a familiar hardback: NOTES ON SPIRITUALISM. Below this, a couple oth hardbacks: one that appears to be a GRIMOIRE (book of spe and the other titled INVOCATIONS.  Green Rev. (mm/dd/yy) 99. INVOCATIONS’ cover features an esoteric sigil. Annie open the book to find that it’s filled with vivid etchings of DEMONIC POSSESSION RITUALS. Annie goes to a MARKED PAGE. It features an illustration beastly man with a hulking body and a strangely effeminat face. He rides a dromedary and wears a crown. Tied to his is a collection of SEVERED HEADS. Behind him is a queue o frolicking ghouls, all headless and all playing instrumen A title reads “King Paimon (God of Mischief)." Annie finds a HIGHLIGHTED PARAGRAPH: "When successfully invoked, Paimon will possess the most vulnerable host. On when the ritual is complete will Paimon be locked into hi ordained host. Once locked in, a new ritual is required t unlock the possession." A sentence underlined in pencil reads: "Paimon is Male, t covetous of a male human body." The next page features an etching of a man sitting atopa mountain of treasure. A caption reads: “The riches to the conjurer." Annie comes to the TITLE PAGE of the book. There isa handwritten NOTE. It reads: My darling, dear, beautiful Annie, Forgive me all the things I could not tell you, as TI truly could not. Please don’t hate me and try not to despair your losses. You will see in the end that they were worth it. Our sacrifice will pale next to the rewards. Love, Mommy Mortified, Annie throws the book into the box, and digs deeper to find TWO PHOTO ALBUMS, familiarly titled “Memories.” Annie flips through one of the albums. For a while, nothi of note. But then she FINDS something... A PHOTO of ANNIE’S MOTHER, 20 years younger, standing wit JOAN, also 20 years younger. They both wear replicas of Annie's NECKLACE - the one bearing the now-familiar sigil Paimon. Stunned, Annie continues through the photo album. She fin SEVERAL MORE PHOTOS FEATURING JOAN, who's often standing the background. Always wearing the necklace. She and Anni Mother were evidently close friends. Another photo: Annie’s mother guides a baby bottle into B CHARLIE’s mouth. The bottle’s milk is polluted with black herbs.  133 134 135 100. Finally, Annie comes to a particularly bizarre photo. It features Joan pouring gold/silver coins over Annie’s Moth head. Annie’s Mother, wearing a tiara, is weeping/laughin tears of joy. They are surrounded by an intimate, APPLAUD audience.

Students are returning to class. Peter walks trembling down the hall. Any lingering kids disperse to enter their classrooms. Peter approaches his classroom, a gnawing apprehension taking him over. Suddenly, from behind Peter, a FLASH of light STREAKS acr the length of the hall. It sweeps past Peter. He FREEZES. The light seems to disappear at Peter’s CLASSROOM. Peter stares at the door.
